author: oaklandmatt
content:
Some songwriting-related morning routine thoughts:

I've been starting my day with doing piano scales and vocal warm ups to a metronome and then singing/ learning a song and recording a voice note of it. (recently it's been Tom Petty Wildflowers at the piano). Then I look at my phone and start my day.

Hard to know for sure if it's causal, but my songwriting abilities have sped up. I'm quicker in sessions, both with topline and tracks. 

I think it's related to several aspects of the morning routine, and they all compound. 

*I'm playing music before I'm on my phone, so I'm outputting music before my brain starts reacting.

*doing scales w piano and voice opens up my vocabulary on both instruments and makes me much more comfortable to sing/play ideas when writing
*doing these to a metronome has improved my timing on all instruments (not just piano and vocal)
*learning a great song and singing it every morning has massively improved my lyrical writing/ improvisation (probably the hardest part of songwriting) by just reinforcing good *sounding* words.
*singing and recording the same song every morning for a few days or a week makes me really THINK about vocals and vocal production. How I'm singing the words, how to push certain vowels in a certain part of my voice, etc 

@Slow Hand  @Ross Fortune @Will Melones @OJ

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes exactly! I've found that the best songs are never calculated, they're always just felt as they're being created. They are magical/ incalculable moments. As soon as people start analyzing – "is this too generic?" "maybe we should have a part like **insert artist**" – the songs loses its magic.

But the paradox is that you can't  just sit around and wait for them to happen. You have to be in motion. So often times building habits and processes (which are calculated) is a great way to keep oneself in the motion of creating things. Piano scales, learning songs, writing a song a day, etc., are just some of the many ways to do this.

And the other aspect is also correct. These are skill building exercises that help the quick translation of creative ideas. It's the emotional and psychological side of workflow. Just like technical workflow – where you want the shortest time between idea an execution – same goes for writing. If you are constantly writing lyrics and singing melodies and playing instruments, when that emotional magical idea arrives, you can translate it more quickly into lyrics, melody, and music.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Depending on the kind of wall that you’re hitting with her, there are a few simple approaches that you can suggest that will get her thinking about the different dimensions of melody and how to play with it:

A) Expansion - How long is the melody? It is a small fragment, or a full sentence? Stretch it out over a longer period of time. Sing it half as fast. Hold certain notes for emphasis.

B) Diminution - Compress parts of the melody into faster runs. Make it shorter. Remove notes. Simplify the melody to its melodic essence.

C) Repetition - Take a fragment of the melody and play it again. And again. And again.

D) Modulation - Take a melodic idea and transpose it to different keys. The first movement of Beethoven’s 5th Symphony is built entirely off of a simple four-note motif. He got a lot of mileage from such a small element.

E) Dynamics - Play with volume or intensity. Encourage her to go from soft to loud, or loud to soft. Accent certain notes for emphasis. This one is really powerful. For inspiration suggest that she try voicing her dynamics like a great horn player might. Get her to clip her notes very short or to make them “bloom” or be soft and round. Make them bark or be breathy.

F) Be Another Instrument - Encourage her to try writing as another instrument with her voice. Sing a bass line. Sing a horn part. Sing percussively like Michael Jackson or James Brown would.

G) Role Playing - Give her a character and a persona to inhabit. Make her sing the same thing as different personalities or people. Pick a melody and then make her sing it in the style of three singers that she’d know.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Given that this is #✍songwriting-talk , I would strongly advise people who want to learn how to be great songwriters to avoid any production at all when doing the practice we're talking about.

It's so much easier (and time consuming) to play with snare drum sounds and production transitions than to stay focused on lyrics and melody. Almost everyone I know, and seemingly everyone that asks questions here, just needs to write lyrics and melody over and over and over.

If you want to get reps to become a producer, that's awesome. Go to #🎹production-talk and talk about those reps.

Trying to also do production while doing the exercises that we're talking about will only slow you down.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes, all the time. But my perspective is sort of tough love: nothing you or I do matters. Even if I make a culturally transcendent song, in 100 years we'll all likely be forgotten.

Ok, so then what? Well, you still have a subjective experience of the world. So what is meaning for you? 

Do you like making things? Do you enjoy the process? Do you feel fulfilled and connected to the experience of life by playing piano or singing or mixing or making weird keyboard sounds? 

I love all that shit so much. When I get stressed out and uninspired, I try to find the ways to get me back into making things. When I do, I always feel better. Piano scales or learning songs or playing guitar for my girlfriend or whatever it is that makes me feel joy.

It's very important for me to have significant parts of my life that are creative and not for any purpose.

author: Pio
content: Something I find really fun and which often gets me out of a rut is picking an artist and imagining you’re in their shoes/writing for them and go. Limit yourself, set a timer, write a song - what words do they use? Listen to a few songs of theirs first and notice what stories they’re interested in telling. I find even if I don’t end up writing a song in their style at all by the end (usually the case) the exercise gets me thinking about the stories I have rolling around my head. Ideas I wouldn’t have thought of as being good for a song. Gets me out of writing the same song too many times, and always makes me realise we have way more songs in us than we thought. Make a weapon out of your empathy and have fun - you can step into anyone’s shoes and try thinking what song you might write if you were there. (The fun challenge is to STLL keep it genuine and authentic to you - kind of paradoxical but I believe heavily in amazing stuff being able to come this way)

author: Zakhiggins
content:
1. I do it first thing in the morning when I wake up before things like my phone ruin my brain for the day. 

2. Make it a routine. I make some time before i have to go anywhere every morning to try and create something. When your brain gets used to the idea that you're going to that place at the same time every day, once you go there then the ideas flow better with time.

3. Understand it's ok to write something bad, with time good ones come. 

4. Understand that a song is never actually finished, it can only be abandoned wherever you chose to abandon it.

4.5. Understand that it's ok to figure out what a song means after you write it.

5. Understand that we're trying to make trees, not tables. (As in sometimes it's not healthy to keep refining something till it's too straight edge and the vitality is gone from it)

6. Said it already but saying it again, don't check your phone before you write

7. I don't always write lyrics. Sometimes i write a melody, sometimes a chord progression, sometimes lyrics. Every now and then i do a session of what i call Lego writing, where i try to see what lyrics i wrote before fit with what melody/chord progression etc. 

8. Oh and did i mention, it ruins my creativity to check my phone before i make anything? 

This is what works for me, hope it helps you!

author: Slow Hand
content:
In this case spaced repetition is your friend. Choose an interval of time that you want to spend practicing a song (10 min, 15 min, 20 min) and practice Song #1 for that amount of time. Then - even if you're not proficient or haven't yet committed the song to memory - move on to practicing Song #2 and let the first song process and consolidate in your memory while you work on Song #2. 

Wash, rinse, repeat until you go through the entire rotation of songs.  If some songs are significantly more difficult to learn or memorize then come back to them more often. The point is to constantly be checking back in on the songs that you're trying to learn just as you're on the threshold of forgetting them.

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m sure we all share this struggle to some degree. I’ve got some projects that I’ve put many hours into, just to let them sit on a hard drive for years.

Co-writing has helped a lot, and has taken some ideas to places I never would have thought to go. The feeling that you have some moral obligation to your collaborators to finish is motivating. When you’re making art for yourself, it doesn’t benefit from those positive forces of peer pressure, and there’s a lack of constraints and no sense of urgency. 

I think making creative decisions is metabolically expensive. It’s easier to defer all decisions, which is why you see DAW-age producers committing to so little until the mix. In the same way you can defer the entire songwriting process, especially if you have someone else’s project or deadline to prioritize over your own.

To be both the creative mind and the executive finisher is a lot of exhausting context switching. Some options might be to split these responsibilities with someone else, or to dedicate separate time to each task. If someone hires me to print stems or solder a patchbay, the last thing I want to do is engage in creativity. But when I get inspired to write, I don’t want to stop and troubleshoot the plug-in that’s crashing the session.

Maybe like the divergence/convergence approach would be to set aside an hour or three at the end of your day to finish ideas you’ve already got brewing—set a timer and finish a song, or a verse. Or, even better yet, dedicate the *end* of your day to play and experimentation. Then the next morning, hopefully with fresh perspective, get in the mood to tie up loose ends and prepare your next steps. You’ve demonstrated that you’re good at wearing that hat for other artists, so you can do it for your songs, too. Just maybe not while you’re in the creative flow.

I’m not practicing what I preach, just brain-dumping. I definitely don’t have this figured out.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I used to do a thing like that with a bunch of buddies in LA every September. 

It started cause I wanted to practice using key changes or modal shifts as a songwriting technique, and so I had rules for myself:

1) first idea that fits, wins. No agonizing over lyrics or Melodies or whatever, if it rhymes and makes some kind of sense, move on with it. 
2) first year: ever song needed a key change or modal shift. Second year: shifting or alt time signatures. Third year: some other esoteric tool I wanted to learn etc…
3) the moment you’re done, record a voice memo and send it to someone. Mistakes and all. 

The key for these rules was the make the quality of the songs less important than the act of writing. But damn if I didn’t get two or three real winners every year.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The other overall point to make is that I find nearly all the great songwriters I know are just comfortable in a session. "Good vibes" in a sense, but also just comfortable generating ideas. They don't really get stuck anywhere. If something isn't working (even if they suggested it), they're comfortable moving forward. Just forward momentum, very little negative energy.

And so much of that is *simply doing it a lot*. It's great to talk about tips and tricks (and yes, morning routines), but mostly it's just putting in time where you're enjoying doing it. 

That's why I think learning songs is so important. It's actually not really about intellectualizing or analyzing what great songs are doing. It's much more just practicing being in the feeling of singing and playing great music. It's the same feeling you're after when you write. By learning great songs and singing them, you get comfortable in that feeling and you're better able to connect to it when writing.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Outside of just getting daily reps, the main goal of this particular practice (the 30 minute write) is that you're setting parameters where you don't have time to decide if something is good. The point is to relieve yourself of any editing and force yourself to quickly write lyrics and melodies. 

It's doing two separate and important things: building muscle memory and teaching to work on instinct.

Building songwriting muscle memory is just like learning a language. You're practicing over and over until you learn how to express yourself emotionally. This is the basics component. You'll learn what notes you can hit and what words rhyme and how rhythms bounce. You'll build a foundation that will become second nature.

Related but distinct, you will learn how to move quickly. It turns out most great songs come in an unthinking way. Until you learn how to write without editing and thinking about what you're doing, you are less likely to write those great songs.

I'm speaking from a lot of personal experience, but also whether it's Hemmingway's "write drunk edit sober," or the Rick Rubin, Pharrell, etc. belief that great songs come from some power outside of ourselves ("Source" or God or whatever), learning to create without being analytical is super super important.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You're way overthinking it and trying to find some "solutions."

The only thing that important is writing A LOT of songs. The only thing. Only. Yes. Only.

Why? Because forced reps is the only way to learn the language of songwriting. You need to practice over and over to get the muscle memory of writing. It's like the language of an instrument or a literal spoken language.

Any books, tips, videos, classes, spiritual paths, etc etc are only useful right now if they get you to write MORE. But really, you do not need them. I strongly disagree with anyone who says otherwise.

FWIW, my 25 years, billions of streams, platinum hit songs, blah blah has taught me that reps are the ONLY foundation. The best songwriters write all the time and didn't really get good until they'd written hundreds to thousands of songs.

@Zack Hames is on the right track. But don't "attempt" to write a song a day. Force yourself to do it. Immerse like you would learning a language. Don't wait to express yourself perfectly, start writing songs like a five-year-old and work your way up. 

Unlike mixing where you need to learn how things like compression work, or like playing guitar where it's important to have someone show you proper technique, you cannot learn how to be a great songwriter by anything other than doing it over and over*.

author: ehutton21
content:
I also think most of my worst writing sessions happen when we don’t clear the air about what someone is looking for. If I’m writing with someone who doesn’t trust themselves as much or doesn’t feel comfortable leading a session because they’re pretty new to writing, I’ll try to be more of an active guide rather than a sounding board. I’ve also had people who get embarassed to write in front of others so I’ll just chill on my phone on the porch for them lmao. 

I think people who are writers and producers struggle to collaborator with that middle ground between seasoned pro/artist with very clear vision, and very “green” artist. They won’t feel comfortable having someone write a whole song for them but they don’t quite trust their own judgement yet either. I think the solution is to practice the idea of commitment.  Sometimes the best writing contribution is letting them do a lot of the lifting, and if the artist gets insecure or flustered, just ask them “well, how do you feel about the idea/line?” or “what about the line feels awkward?” That way you’re helping them to actually make decisions—now they’ll be able to write with you or anyone else, or completely solo.

Quote time 

“Instead of saying, “I’m stuck, I can’t come up with anything good,” it’s far more effective to say, “I’ve finished this, and now I need to make it better.” Or possibly, “I finished this, and it can’t be made better, but now I’m ready to do the new thing, because look at all I’ve learned.”

author: alecdibell2

@Zack Hames finding a teacher for what you’re looking to improve on could take some shopping around. I think it would be helpful to move away from practice only being playing along to your productions.

You’re going to develop better groove if all you’re listing to is your own playing. So I’d start practicing some grooves solo, no click for now, no music. Listen closely to drummers that you love that have that feel throughout songs. Learn their grooves, play along to their songs for a bit.

I think after you take time to play only listening to yourself, and playing along to other songs with a great feel, it’ll be easier to integrate those philosphies into your own productions.

My drum lessons when I was younger made me stiff and less creative, so finding the right teacher is soooo important. It wasn’t until I played solo to make the drums impactful by themselves, and played along to a ton of hiatus kaiyote and esperanza spalding that i was able to have a musical feel

I think communicating that through text is *incredibly* difficult. What i usually do is try to confirm by describing what they're talking about BACK to them while also using the correct terminology.

He's incredible, amazing writer and has amazing ears but does not have any training or speaks with any technicality with almost anything in his life. It would be almost impossible to actually break those habits for him, he just doesn't care.

author: Deleted User
content:
There may be two ways of approaching this

1: Trying to make the better versions of ‘same type of songs‘.  I do this myself, using same moves that have worked before I can make a better version of the same type of song. 

2: Copy from style you are unfamiliar with. This can get you out of making ‘same type of songs’

I think there are main four elements of musical habits: rhythm chords cadence/resolution tempo 

you may find there are a few key things that you gravitate towards like your “home” in all four of those. You can explore outside of the patterns that you lean on in those four elements if you want to prioritize breaking out of some of the habitual choices.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: But beyond that. You can comp the gibberish together to make the most compelling melody for the part your writing to. Then just loop that part. And start to sing with your comp. Ask yourself what's the mood of the song, what mood am I in. And just kinda flow with it. Like improvising on an instrument. Its a muscle so it will take time and effort. The more often you sit down and improvise melody the easy this will be. Doesn't always have to be a voice exercise. 15 mins of mindless melody exploration on a guitar or piano will stretch the same brain muscles.

author: Brian Reynolds
content:
I'm always in the daw. Always recording.

Sometimes melody first. But mostly drums first.

Build an instrumental just chasing intuition, quickly. 2-3 melody parts and a bass line on top of drums. And youve got a chorus loop. 

Then take that improvisational melody muscle and apply it to the vocal melody. 

Im not a big humming guy, I get to words pretty quickly. But will start with common phrases to me like,  "runnin runnin runnin round runnin runnin runnin down" I have a few others.

I start to land on a melody, with a feeling and story. That I haven't told. Sometimes it takes 90 seconds, sometimes 5-10 mins. 

Record and comp till I have what I like. Than do all the background vocals. 

Then start muting a couple of the melody parts. Find my verses.

Rinse repeat the process above. But now I know the story and I just have to find the melody and the thru line narrative.

Depending on how the verses feel running into the chorus. Or short length of track. I'll write a bridge 

Melodyne the vocals.

Structure the song.

Mix the song.

Upload the song.

Make another.

This usually takes 2-4 days, intermittent with regular life.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
As I'm sure you already know , there is no such thing as enough. It's like how perfection doesn't exist. 

It may be easier to think of being a writer on a spectrum from hobbyist to full-time artist. The one end is the hobbyist who does it whenever they want and have time (other priorities take precedent). The other end is the artist who is compelled to do it and it has to turn it off in order to live a normal life.

Most people here are somewhere in between. For most of us, the key is to do a combination of two things:

1. Find every way possible at all times to joyfully write. Direct yourself toward it with how live. Write silly things for fun, have a guitar you like to play next to the place you always like to sit, write emotional things for catharsis, write with other people for the collaborative joy, sing in the shower, write on different instruments that feel inspiring, etc etc 

2. The harder part is developing habits and practices that keep you consistent. It's easy to write when it's fun. It's harder to write when it's not fun, and that's the time to make sure you're doing it. Daily practices, schedules, deadlines (self imposed or otherwise) are the best way to do this.

author: Deleted User
content: I deal with (unintentional) inconsistent tempo and some time even time signature/pulse pretty often when working with songwriters and artists. It seems to solve the problem when you tap your feet to the melody. Then you would realize that the tempo has changed. And count 1-2-3-4 or whatever the meter is. So you don’t end up unintentionally having an extra beat because of words and disrupt everything else. A lot of writers ask people for beats first for this reason, but if the melody doesn’t stand on it’s own- relying on the beats will do more harm than good in my opinion. They often end up being mediocre melodies from my experience because there’s already tons of subdivisions and grooves in the beat and the topliner is relying on that to drive the rhythmic feel. But also beats need to come in with pocket so there are space for the vocal melody to fit in. It would be good for writers to start without a beat or instrumentals and it would be good for beatmakers to practice leaving vocal pockets when starting with a beat first

author: Josh
content: I’d focus on linear grooves, rudiments, and dynamics above all. Simple shit like 8-8-16 exercises with various dynamic changes will help you out a ton. Rudiments will help you understand how things like flams across a hi-hat and snare will have their place, and linear grooves will help you feel across the kit while also being hella selective and very minimal to your approach as far as writing drums go. The best drummers can overplay the fuck out of a song but choose not to because often times the simple things played extremely thoughtfully so much better. 🙂

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
I was gonna ask what your use case was, but if you’re sending out a lot of beats it make sense! 

Whenever you collect an idea/beat to go through later, conceptualize it as sending a package to your future self. If there’s too much noise, or if you’re banking on your future self to do too much heavy lifting or filtering, the packages will not be useful to you and it will be a waste of time. But if you have a strong use case and a system for processing it in the future, as it sounds like you have, it makes a lot of sense!

Personally I like to only save the things that inspire me in the moment - mainly because I know I will lose inspiration if I go through too many things that don’t resonate later.

content:
Asking for Chat GPT to replicate someone's style in any convincing way is a massive lift to ask of it. Joni's style is emotionally insightful, nuanced, and witty. Her choices are informed by a lifetime of experience and point of view. It's almost ineffable at times. It feels like magic. Poetry is elusive. Most humans can barely do it themselves at that level. Asking these programs to perform at that level is... a lot.

There's a meme that I came across recently. It was the jazz saxophonist Chris Potter describing how in order to do what he does he has to be practicing at a level that is 10x beyond what he might actually play in a session. In a sense he needs creative and technical headroom to arrive at what the result that the rest of us witness.

Some poetry follows this same principle. It's deeply, deeply ingrained and considered. The best poetry resonates and hints at things that aren't even explicitly mentioned. There's an iceberg of practice and experience beneath the surface of what we see. All Chat GPT sees is the surface. The final results that we're feeding it. It has no conception of the experiences that it's trying to replicate so it's approximations of something so complex and nuanced are likely to fall flat.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think that is what I am after; How do you say the same idea or concept/story but deliver it tastefully. Just like the same E major chord could be delivered in different voicings and different style of playing or instruments even. 

Maybe it’s just about paying attention to it more. I generally pay more attention to music than words by default, so that might be a factor that plays into it. 

Technically- with drums for example, you can use the same tools, try to play it or sequence it with the feel as close to it as possible, and break down what’s on it in terms of processing. If I go further, I can look at how the drums are interacting with the rest of the ensemble. If I just want to rip off the drums from a song, the first three will pretty much get me there. 

D’Angelo’s Voodoo is an album I constantly go back to study for the band interaction. Questlove is usually playing straight eighth notes, and very simple pattern. but how open the hihat is, and where he’s hitting, and when he makes the choices to pop the hihat out or kind of let it hide behind the instrumentation is very interesting. Perhaps subtle spontaneous decisions like that isn’t really replicable but I just take it in physically and try to see why he made this by looking at what other instruments are doing. You can just pay attention to how he plays hi hat and go wild playing just the hat along

author: jonmatteson
content:
Wanted to ask producers who also write with artist what their writing sessions look like? 
Are you preparing tracks before hand? Making stuff on the spot?
Sitting at the computer or sitting together with acoustic guitars beforehand?
How long are you hanging before you start writing?
I find my hangs going pretty long especially on the first write with someone but that usually leads to better lyrical content. However I want to be more intentional with our time without it feeling rushed. 

I’m working on my flow and would love some insight into what other people’s process looks like.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’ve tried different ways with hangs- I’m still figuring out. And I typically don’t touch lyrics anymore because I’ve found that I’m not that great at lyrics yet and if I don’t have a line (which I usually don’t….), it’s better to leave it be for the longevity of relationship because lyrics can be one of the most personal things in music making because… it is literal. If you are more lyrics person, I think you can get a lot of value out of hanging out. 

First thing is creating safe space- and it really depends on person to person. Some people never open up, some people can open up immediately. In my experience, the more experienced they are - the more they tend to be the latter. I think how much time you spend on it can be dependent on this. You mentioned wanting to be more intentional, one idea that came to my mind is communicating this from the get go. Obviously there are going to be times where bring this up can be weird in the beginning of the session, but it should get them to think about opening up as part of work at the very least. It needs to be done carefully of course

The other part of it is understanding the person themselves. Their general vibe and energy. It’s easier to tell with some folks, and it’s harder to know what kind of person it is with some other folks. regarding this, I find diving into work right away helps feel it out. my job is often to constantly create ideas and inspirations. I can often gather some information from how they respond to different ideas. 

Lastly, I used to spend a lot of time hanging up until very recently and I found it’s so much more productive to just work and bond through that experience. Nature of work calls for connecting on a personal level, but it doesn’t require it. I’ve been trying to take it easy on getting closer with people, and focusing on the overall experience of collaboration and it has been making sessions more productive. So I plan on sticking with this way for a bit and see how it goes!

author: Pio
content:
Late to this one, hope your songwriting journey is going great this past while! 

If you’re still looking for more on this, and don’t mind a little reading, I was recommended Pat Pattinson’s Write Better Lyrics years ago and I found it a super helpful tool - I loved the recommendation of a 10 min a day exercise of ‘object writing’, and also the idea of thinking about your verses as a way of ‘loading’ story and fuel for your choruses. 

Jeff Tweedy also has an even shorter but really uplifting book on writing called ‘How to Write One Song’, which is excellent. It’s more geared towards the personal, less towards industry, but I’m so convicted that writing personal songs IS the way to reach others that I would definitely recommend it too.

author: Pio
content:
And if you don’t wanna go buying books, I’d recommend possibly trying out the daily practice of object writing; you could even try it for a week or so, and you’ll end up getting interesting imagery, some of which you may be able to use in your songs - but if you stick at it a bit (I find if I do it solidly in the mornings for a week or two it just warms my brain right up for writing throughout the day) it can help get your brain into that mode, so that when you go into your writing sessions later, your brain is already making those connections. Just an option of course - everyone’s got their own way with lyric, it really is so personal. Whatever tools help, use em, whatever tools don’t, chuck em. 

I just mention these things bc you talk about making the songs ‘real’, and I feel that - I love trying to get a song to feel properly grounded, with a sense of place and reality. Best solution I’ve found is to just leave a bit of me in there - somehow it’s like people can feel when songwriting is ‘real’, so I just try to make sure my heart is in/behind each line, keep them smooth, rinse repeat 

Would love to crack open this topic again too, curious on more peoples thoughts on this stuff, thanks for opening this up  @OJ,

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Prompt for a fun question for the group: Is there a workflow that you’ve found to be a common denominator between your songs for how you write them?

I’ve been writing songs for my current project by using a compilation of many notes, voice memos, journal entries, letters I’ve written then later converted to lyrics, etc. From there I used my current craft to sculpt them into each track that captures a theme, emotion, or something else that stood out to me.

I often wonder how other active song writers put their finished pieces together. Is it as scattered as my process? Do they usually sit with an idea and write it linearly, line by line? A combination of things?


I’d love to read other people’s processes and mindsets, if anyone would like to share.
